data.output: Jim stepped foot into the car showroom and was browsing the various models and makes of vehicles available in his price range.  The manager approached Jim to enquire what kind of care he would like and whether it would suit his needs.  Jim explained that he previously had a Toyota RAV4 which was a diesel vehicle and as much as he loved his car, he told the manager of the car showroom that it kept breaking down and costing him money.  On further questioning by the manager, they both decided that due to Jim only doing short distances in his car, never driving distances or driving on the motorway, that a petrol car would be much more suited to his needs.  The manager explained how a diesel car needed long distance driving and was not really suitable for Jim's situation.  Jim finally signed off on a new petrol car, the manager agreed he could drive it off the lot that day if Jim was willing to pump the gas on the way home as it was low in fuel already. Jim readily agreed and happily drove his new car away, stopping to pump his new petrol vehicle on the way home.

During one night at my local gym i bumped into Vin Diesel who commented on my abilty to lift my weight correctly. He decided to show me a better way to get my pump on. Whilst given the chance to ask him, i quipped if he had any siblings named after petrol.

I wanted to have some fun while I was off work. I wanted to make a rocket so I got some petrol. I was lucky as I nearly get diesel. Anyway, I put a few drops of petrol in a plastic bottle and used a pump to vapourise the petrol. I put a match to the nosel of the bottle and it shot into the air.

A car mechanic had the surprise of his life when his wife gave birth to three babies instead of one! As he and his wife stared down at their three new children, the midwife stood behind them and asked a very valid question. "So, what will you call them?"   You see, they had a name for baby number one. They were naming him after his favourite WWF wrestler, Diesel. But the other two...? He began to sweat. With the pressure of both his wife and the midwives eyes on him, he blurted out the first two things he could think of.   "Their names are Diesel, Petrol and Pump!"  And that is the story of how their children got their very unique names. Thanks Dad.

Marc was, as his friends would describe him, a 'petrol head': he loved cars, motorbikes, trucks, pretty much anything that looked good and could hit high speeds. When Marc graduated university, he moved to a small town and adopted a dog, named Diesel, to keep him company. Marc and Diesel would drive around the town in Marc's Ford Mustang, listening to rock music, with the windows down. Let's pump up the volume! Marc shouted to Diesel as they drove away into the sunset.

not a long time ago and not in a galaxy far far away. no, this story is a lot different than star wars but shares certain elements such as tyranny, oppression, and depreciation of society. the lust for energy, petrol in particular, led to the long-anticipated world war. people tried to stop using vehicles powered by high-carbon emitting substances like diesel, but that was not of use. after a certain point, even though many machinery switched to electricity-fueled engines, people could not find sufficient ways to pump the engines with electricity.

It was a sunny day and little Mia's favourite place to play was next to the old pink water pump hidden in the wildflowers at her grandma's house. At only 6 years old, she didn't quite know what it was but had painted, decorated and pretended it was magic for as long as she could remember. Her grandma would tell her of the days when the big petrol and diesel trucks would come rolling through the town but Mia wasn't interested in the history, only in the fantasy worlds she could create in her beautiful hideout.

One evening, after a long trip to see family I was about to make my way to take the long drive home, around 2 hours away. I had had a fun time, but honestly I was just exhausted. Every step to the car felt like bliss, knowing I would soon be home and ready to sleep in my own bed. I opened the door and went to turn the keys, ready to leave, I would miss my family but it was time to make my own departure. I turned the keys, but rather than the usual hum I would expect to hear I just hear a harsh sound resonating from the engine. Something is wrong, this is not normal. I make my way out of the car and back to the house I had just moments ago been so delighted to depart from.  "Hey everyone, i'm back." I announced, with a twinge of disappointment in my voice. "It seems my car isn't starting, did anything happen to it while I was here?" "Well, actually" my youngest sibling spoke up. She had recently got a license of her own, so it was surprising she would be the one to speak up about issues with a car. "We don't have a station nearby, so I had hoped to help out a bit by pumping some of our own fuel in before you left!" There was a look of confusion across the family, no one sure what she meant by our own fuel. "Wait, you didn't specify. What kind of fuel was it?" I replied to her. "Oh! It was a canister of diesel, every car uses that nowadays, right?" she gleefully explained. There was a heavy silence across the room, especially on the adults. I took a breath before uttering "My car only uses petrol...".

Once upon a time, there were three sentient cars, called Petrol, Diesel and Pump. Petrol was a red sporty car who loved to drive fast. Diesel was older, brown and reliable. Pump was a small silver car. They loved to drive around together and have adventures. However, Petrol was always getting cross at Diesel and Pump for not being able to drive as fast as he could. They decided to teach him a lesson. One day, they drove and drove and drove for as long as they could. Petrol felt himself running out of fuel and begged them to stop and wait. They carried on and left him behind at the side of the road. After a little while, they returned and found him feeling very sorry for himself. "See?" they told him, "we may be older and smaller, but we are still good, st and reliable

Marly stood staring at the petrol pump. "What the bloody hell do I put in this thing? There's no way to tell if it's petrol or diesel! I'll just try diesel in this hole at the back.". The horse's eyes grew huge and it neighed loudly.

The pump for my bicycle broke the other day. It got a puncture. Would you be able to believe the irony, because I certainly wouldn't! This meant that until I could source a new one, or fix that one, I was borrowing and driving my mum's car. The only problem with this, was that the first time I took it to get filled up I was not sure whether it took petrol or diesel...

It was still another 10 miles to the next petrol or diesel pump. I didn't even know what this old battered car took but whatever it was it was running on fumes. I'd soon know about it if it was diesel as i think i heard once that you cant let a diesel tank run drive or the engine would go kaput. Every extra mile the car got was one fewer to the safety and one more away them.

Whenever I thought of him. It was always with a sense of pain and contemplation. Did he really have to travel that night? Into the eerie void. With little concern that the choices he made to fill up at the station and take the precarious route would ensure his finality. We were told the car went up in flames when he crashed into the oak tree. His petrol tank was full. The tree remained stoic. It could have been diesel, it would have made little difference to the outcome. We told him not to leave. To drive to the petrol station. It's ironic. That a pump. A vessel used so commonly could be the source of his demise. I could not view the mangled metal visage

Brian was a down on his luck kids football coach, he had to take training the following morning but last week all the kids complained because most of the footballs he had in his bag were flat, but he didn't have a pump to inflate them. He quickly jumped in his car to go to buy a pump, but broke down shortly after setting off because he'd put diesel in his car instead of petrol. He had to call a breakdown serive to come and pick him and his car up.

I was driving my petrol lawnmower whilst maintaining my 3 acres of fields. In a lapse of judgement I accidentally crashed into a water pump that irrigated the farm. Whilst the pump was being repaired, I had to hire a diesel generator to replace the pump.

the sun was shining, there was a gentle breeze and I was enjoying the drive through the countryside.   i was on my way to join other members of the Petrol Head Club for a fun day out.    I was wearing my favourite Diesel jeans and club T-shirt - i thought i looked great.    i switched radio channels to the Pump fm and sang alon

The car was travelling too fast down the road. He couldn't keep control of the vehicle and he felt panic run through his veins. And in a flash, he had careered into the barriers where the stop and pump was smashed into it. Petrol and diesel was flung everywhere.

I made it a few miles down the road before I heard that terrible noise. The car rolled to a stop by the side of the road and I realised my mistake. I'd put diesel in my petrol car! They were right beside each other at the pump. Now the long wait for the recovery man, how embarrassing!

Laurel and Dan were driving through a town in their new diesel car. It was a nice town, where people were extremely welcoming and happy. They stopped at the local inn and found themselves in the company of some lovely ladies. They were offered free drinks and they found a nice hot meal to warm their bodies. Ahh, but it was time to go since they couldn't be there forever. Little did they know that they were stuck there. the locals needed gas to prepare their meal, so they used a pump to suck all the petrol out of their car. Luckly, they had some horses they could exchange for the car, if they could tame them.

As the day grows darker and I find myself having to do the weekly shopping it is with glee that I look over my shoulder whilst driving past a petrol pump. What a relic of the recent past, having had to put diesel in my old car and feeling like a slave to the big oil corporations that are stuck in their ways. Nowadays, I go shopping whilst my electric car charges, giving me time and not worrying what my actions impact our environment. To all the naysayers I say just this, don't wack it before you try it.

I was driving down the highway, on my way to visit my uncle at his farm when i decided to pull over and take a break. I ran into the shop to grab some food and drink as I still had a few hours to go before reaching the farm. I checked the car and thought i better top up the tank before going too much further, so I drove on down to the pump. As it was a long journey and my beat up little truck was not up to the try, I hired a car and it took me a good few minutes to work out if I was driving a petrol or diesel car. Just as I was filling up, a stranger walked up to me asking for change. I thought what was the worst that could happen, so handed over the loose change I had. Very politely he thanked for my kindness, little did I know this was going to set off a chain of events I could never have imagined.

Keisha loved many things, but her 2 favourite things in the world were the smell of petrol and sunny days. Keisha also did not mind the smell of diesel but often found if she went to the petrol station to help pump her husbands car the diesel pump would often get stuck which was one of Keisha's irritants. On this particular sunny Saturday morning Keisha set out to the nearest park to her meet her friends to have a picnic, she decided to walk but really wished she drove so the smell of petrol would be breezing through her hair.

Mischa and her family were going to collect their three new puppies. Mischa and her brother Tommy could not wait to see their little faces again. "What are we going to call the puppies?!" the siblings dad asked. "Petrol, Diesel and Pump!" Tommy beamed.

There was a beautiful car. It had a shiny exterior with beautiful and intricate paintwork. Its interior was luxurious. It was unknown at first whether petrol or diesel would fuel the car. It was discovered through research, rather than just to pump the car with either petrol or diesel, that the car runs on petrol.

The man had quickly realised that he filled his tank with petrol instead of diesel when the engine cut out. Trying to pump it out of his tank was impossible as he had not tools to do so. He tried calling around to see if anyone had a means to fix his problem, but alas he has to call a local garage to pick him and his car up. He was hoping and praying that his car would be able to be fixed. It doesn't look good.
